questions.text: Which feature is not associated with trachoma? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Haab's Stria

 

Haab's stria is not associated with trachoma. These horizontal breaks in Descemet's membrane occur in congenital glaucoma, not in trachomatous infection. Trachoma is a chronic keratoconjunctivitis caused by Chlamydia trachomatis with specific clinical features and sequelae that don't include Haab's stria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herbert's Pit: This is incorrect because Herbert's pits are specifically characteristic of trachoma. They are oval or circular pitted scars left after healing of Herbert follicles in the limbal area. These pits remain as permanent sequelae of the disease.

 

Option B. Arlt's line: This is incorrect because Arlt's line is a defining feature of trachoma. It refers to the linear scar present in the sulcus subtarsalis that forms during the cicatricial phase of trachoma as part of the scarring process.

 

Option C. Leber cells: This is incorrect because Leber cells are components of trachomatous follicles. These large multinucleated cells are found in the central part of each follicle along with mononuclear histiocytes and lymphocytes. Their presence helps differentiate trachoma follicles from follicles of other forms of follicular conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Trachoma's pathognomonic features include Herbert's pits, Arlt's line, and follicles containing Leber cells, while Haab's stria belong to a completely different pathology (congenital glaucoma).

questions.text: What are the rounded, depressed regions of necrotic limbal follicles known as? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herbert's pits

 

Herbert's pits are the rounded, depressed regions that form after the healing of necrotic limbal follicles in trachoma. They represent a characteristic feature of the cicatricial phase of trachoma and remain as permanent sequelae of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Von Arlt's line: This is incorrect because Arlt's line refers to a linear scar present in the sulcus subtarsalis (the groove where the palpebral conjunctiva connects with the skin). It is another cicatricial feature of trachoma but is not related to necrotic limbal follicles. Arlt's line forms during the scarring stage of trachoma.

 

Option C. Fuchs' spots: This is incorrect because Fuchs' spots (or islets of Vogt) are whitish infiltrates seen in front of the head of a progressive pterygium. They are unrelated to trachoma or necrotic limbal follicles, being instead associated with pterygium formation.

 

Option D. Horner-Trantas dots: This is incorrect because Horner-Trantas spots are discrete whitish raised dots along the limbus seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis. They represent eosinophilic accumulations at the limbus, not necrotic follicles. They are characteristic of allergic conjunctival disease, not trachomatous infection.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Herbert's pits are pathognomonic scarring lesions of trachoma that form at the limbus after healing of Herbert's follicles, appearing as oval or circular pitted scars that persist as permanent markers of previous trachomatous infection.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male from a rural background presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a history of difficulty in vision for 10 days. He reports that vegetative material fell into his left eye about 15 days ago. On examination, an ulcerative lesion in the cornea with feathery margins and creamy exudates is observed. A few satellite lesions are also noted. What is the most likely etiologic agent? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fusarium sp.

 

This is a clear case of fungal keratitis, most likely caused by Fusarium species. The key diagnostic features include:

 

  • History of vegetative matter injury (classic risk factor for fungal keratitis)
  • Feathery margins of the corneal ulcer (characteristic of fungal etiology)
  • Creamy exudates in the ulcer bed
  • Presence of satellite lesions (strongly suggestive of fungal etiology)
  • Rural background (increased exposure to vegetative materials)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corynebacterium diphtheriae:

 

  • Causes membranous conjunctivitis rather than corneal ulcers with feathery margins
  • Not typically associated with vegetative matter injury
  • Does not produce satellite lesions
  • Rare cause of keratitis in the modern era
  • Not associated with creamy exudates in the cornea

 

Option C. Acanthamoeba sp.:

 

  • Though associated with corneal ulcers, it commonly affects contact lens wearers
  • Presents with severe pain disproportionate to clinical signs
  • Characteristic ring infiltrate rather than feathery margins
  • Radial keratoneuritis is a pathognomonic early sign
  • Does not typically produce satellite lesions

 

Option D. Streptococcus pneumoniae:

 

  • Causes ulcus serpens (hypopyon corneal ulcer)
  • Has oval, yellowish-white densely opaque ulcer with sharply defined margins
  • No feathery margins or satellite lesions
  • Often associated with nasolacrimal duct obstruction
  • Typically produces hypopyon rather than creamy exudates

 

Educational Objective:

 

A corneal ulcer with feathery margins, satellite lesions, and history of vegetative matter injury strongly suggests fungal keratitis, with Fusarium species being the most common causative agent.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a limbal scar presents to the ophthalmology clinic with moderately defective vision for both near and far. Clinical examination reveals a wide and deep anterior chamber, iridodonesis, and a dark pupillary reflex. Vision of 6/6 is achieved with a corrective lens of +11D. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aphakia

 

The clinical presentation strongly indicates Aphakia. The key diagnostic findings include deep anterior chamber, iridodonesis (tremulousness of iris), and dark pupillary reflex (aphakic pupil). Additionally, the high hyperopic correction (+11D) needed to achieve normal vision is characteristic of aphakia. Presence of Limbal scar in his given scenario indicates a post-surgical condition differentiating it from simple posterior dislocation. Posterior dislocation occurs when all zonules are severed, allowing the lens to fall into the vitreous cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pseudophakia: This refers to a state where an artificial intraocular lens has been implanted. There's no mention of any surgical history or presence of an IOL, making this diagnosis incorrect.

 

Option C. Hypermetropia: While the patient requires a hyperopic correction (+11D), this is far beyond typical hypermetropia. Primary hypermetropia wouldn't explain the deep anterior chamber, iridodonesis, or dark pupillary reflex.

 

Option D. Posterior Dislocation of Lens: While sharing similar features (deep AC, iridodonesis), the lens would still be present in the vitreous cavity. On fundus examination, a posteriorly dislocated lens would be visible. Would be described as "lens in vitreous cavity" rather than merely a dark pupillary reflex

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aphakia presents with the classic triad of deep anterior chamber, iridodonesis, and dark pupillary reflex, requiring high plus power correction (+10D to +12D) due to the complete absence of the crystalline lens that normally contributes +15-16D to the eye's refractive power.

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby presents with bilateral cataract. A urine test is requested to suspect? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Galactosemia

 

Galactosemia is associated with congenital cataract, specifically presenting as "oil droplet central lens opacities" in infants. Galactosemia occurs due to deficiency of either galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (classical galactosemia) or galactokinase. In a 6-month-old with bilateral cataract, galactosemia should be suspected, and diagnosis is established by detecting reducing substances in urine when milk and milk products are consumed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Homocystinuria: This condition is associated with lens subluxation, typically in the inferior nasal direction, not congenital cataract. Diagnosis is established by the sodium nitroprusside test for homocystine in urine, but this wouldn't be the first suspicion in a 6-month-old with bilateral cataract.

 

Option C. Hyperlysinemia: This is an extremely rare condition caused by deficiency of the enzyme lysine alpha-ketoglutarate reductase. While occasionally associated with ectopia lentis (lens displacement), it's not characteristically linked to congenital cataract in infants.

 

Option D. Sulphite oxidase deficiency: This is a very rare autosomal recessive disorder of sulphur metabolism associated with ectopia lentis, not congenital cataract. It's a fatal disease with death usually occurring before 5 years of age.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In an infant presenting with bilateral cataract, galactosemia should be suspected and investigated with urine testing for reducing substances, as early dietary intervention can prevent progression and potentially reverse lens changes.

questions.text: Identify the surgical step shown in the image given below: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Capsulorrhexis

 

  • Capsulorrhexis is a step in the conventional extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) method.
  • It is a method of anterior capsulotomy, where an opening is made in the anterior capsule of the lens.
  • Anterior capsulotomy can be done by 3 methods:
    1. Can-opener's technique
    2. Linear capsulotomy or envelope technique
    3. Continuous curvilinear capsulorrhexis
  • Continuous curvilinear capsulorrhexis (CCC) is considered superior because it does not leave any edges or tears when done correctly.
  • Trypan blue dye can be used to stain the lens capsule for better visibility during the procedure.
  • In ECCE, a portion of the anterior capsule of the lens is removed, allowing extraction of the lens nucleus and cortex while leaving the remainder of the anterior capsule, the posterior capsule, and the zonular support intact.
  • After capsulorrhexis, hydro dissection is performed using a balanced salt solution to separate the corticonuclear mass from the capsule.
  • Removal of lens nucleus and aspiration of the cortex is done using a two-way irrigation and aspiration cannula.
  • An intraocular lens (IOL) is then implanted, and the incision is closed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hydrodissection: Hydrodissection involves injecting fluid under the anterior capsule to separate the lens nucleus from the cortex and the capsule. This procedure follows capsulorrhexis and serves to facilitate the removal of the lens material. The image does not show fluid injection or the separation process typical of hydrodissection.

 

Option C. Intraocular lens implantation: This step involves placing an intraocular lens (IOL) into the capsular bag once the lens material has been removed. In the image, there is no indication of an IOL being handled or inserted, as the focus is solely on manipulating the capsule itself, which precedes the IOL implantation in the surgical sequence.

 

Option D. Lens aspiration: Lens aspiration involves the removal of the lens cortex and nucleus, usually through suction or phacoemulsification, following the capsulorrhexis and hydrodissection steps. The image does not depict any equipment or actions associated with the aspiration of lens material, such as a phacoemulsification handpiece or suction device.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Capsulorrhexis is characterized by the creation of a controlled and continuous tear in the anterior capsule of the lens, which is essential for accessing and removing the lens material in cataract surgery. This method provides a clear opening without leaving jagged edges, which is crucial for the structural integrity of the remaining capsule necessary for IOL placement.

choices.text: Difference in the axial length of the eyeballs
Difference in the size of corneas
Difference in the size of pupils
Difference in the size of images formed by the two eyes

questions.text: What does aniseikonia refer to? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Difference in the size of images formed by the two eyes

 

Aniseikonia is defined as a condition wherein the images projected to the visual cortex from the two retinae are abnormally unequal in size and/or shape. Up to 5% aniseikonia is well tolerated by the visual system. The term specifically refers to the difference in image size perception between the two eyes, not the physical difference in ocular structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Difference in the axial length of the eyeballs: This is incorrect. While differences in axial length may cause anisometropia (unequal refractive error between eyes), it is not aniseikonia. Anisometropia can lead to aniseikonia, but they are distinct conditions. Anisometropia refers to the optical state when the total refraction of the two eyes is unequal.

 

Option B. Difference in the size of corneas: This is incorrect. Different corneal sizes may contribute to refractive differences between eyes but don't directly define aniseikonia. Aniseikonia specifically refers to the perceived image size difference, not the anatomical difference in corneal dimensions.

 

Option C. Difference in the size of pupils: This is incorrect. Pupil size differences (anisocoria) affect light entry but not image size perception. Pupils regulate light entry to the eye but don't significantly impact the size of images formed on the retina or perceived by the visual cortex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aniseikonia represents a perceptual phenomenon where the brain receives differently sized images from each eye, which can result from optical correction of anisometropia, retinal displacement, or cortical processing differences. It's a critical concept in understanding visual discomfort in patients with high refractive correction differences between eyes.

choices.text: Congested vessels cannot be moved with a cotton bud

questions.text: Which of the following is indicative of episcleritis rather than scleritis? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Blanching of vessels with 10% phenylephrine

 

Blanching of vessels with 10% phenylephrine is characteristic of episcleritis and helps differentiate it from scleritis. This occurs because:

 

  • In episcleritis, the inflammation affects the episcleral vessels which are superficial
  • These superficial vessels constrict in response to topical vasoconstrictors like phenylephrine
  • This vasoconstrictive response results in blanching of the redness
  • The deeper vessels involved in scleritis are not affected by topical vasoconstrictors

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Severe Pain:

 

  • Severe pain is characteristic of scleritis, not episcleritis
  • Episcleritis typically causes mild discomfort or irritation
  • Scleritis pain is often described as deep, boring, and may wake the patient at night
  • The pain in scleritis may radiate to the temple and forehead

 

Options B. Tenderness:

 

  • Marked tenderness on palpation is typical of scleritis
  • Episcleritis shows minimal or no tenderness
  • The tenderness in scleritis corresponds to the area of inflammation
  • This tenderness is due to deeper inflammation affecting scleral tissue

 

Options C. Congested vessels cannot be moved with a cotton bud:

 

  • Immobile vessels are characteristic of scleritis
  • In episcleritis, the vessels are superficial and can be moved with a cotton bud
  • The immobility in scleritis occurs because the inflammation is within the scleral tissue
  • This is a useful clinical test to differentiate between the two conditions

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blanching of vessels with vasoconstrictors like phenylephrine is a key diagnostic feature of episcleritis, distinguishing it from scleritis which shows no blanching due to deeper vessel involvement.

questions.text: What is the primary action of the superior oblique muscle? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intorsion, Abduction, and Depression

 

The superior oblique muscle has three actions that can be remembered using the mnemonic "SOLID" where "SO" stands for Superior Oblique and "LID" stands for the three actions: Lateral (abduction), Intorsion, and Depression. The primary action of superior oblique is intorsion, the secondary action is depression, and the tertiary action is abduction. This functional pattern is consistent across all standard ophthalmology references.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adduction, Intorsion, and Depression: This is incorrect because the superior oblique causes abduction, not adduction. Adduction is primarily the action of the medial rectus muscle.

 

Option C.Abduction, Extorsion, and Depression: This is incorrect because superior oblique causes intorsion, not extorsion. Extorsion is the action of the inferior oblique muscle.

 

Options D. Elevation, Intorsion, and Adduction: This is incorrect on two counts. Superior oblique causes depression (not elevation) and abduction (not adduction). Elevation is primarily the action of the superior rectus and inferior oblique muscles.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The superior oblique muscle primarily produces intorsion, with secondary action of depression and tertiary action of abduction (lateral movement). This can be remembered with the mnemonic "SOLID" (Superior Oblique - Lateral, Intorsion, Depression).

questions.text: Which condition is suggested by a painful red eye with a small and irregular pupil? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Iritis/Iridocyclitis

 

Iritis/iridocyclitis classically presents with a painful red eye with circumcorneal congestion. The key diagnostic sign is the constricted and irregular pupil, which results from inflammation of the iris causing sphincter spasm and the formation of posterior synechiae. This pattern of symptoms forms a distinctive clinical picture that helps differentiate anterior uveitis from other causes of red eye.

 

Visual Support: In acute iritis, you would observe:

 

  • Pain localized to the eye
  • Circumcorneal redness (ciliary flush)
  • Constricted, irregular pupil
  • Cells in the anterior chamber
  • Keratic precipitates on the cornea

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Conjunctivitis: While conjunctivitis causes redness, it presents with foreign body sensation and itching rather than localized pain. The pupil remains normal in size and shape, unlike the constricted irregular pupil seen in iritis. The congestion is conjunctival rather than circumcorneal.

 

Option B. Corneal Ulcer: Though corneal ulcers present with pain and redness, the pupil is typically constricted but not irregular. The primary features are corneal ulceration/suppuration, which are not mentioned in the question scenario.

 

Option D. Acute Glaucoma: Acute glaucoma presents with a fixed, mid-dilated pupil (not constricted and irregular). It typically causes severe pain radiating beyond the eye, often with headache, nausea and vomiting, and marked elevation of intraocular pressure.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A constricted, irregular pupil with circumcorneal redness and localized eye pain is the classic presentation of anterior uveitis (iritis/iridocyclitis) and should prompt immediate ophthalmologic evaluation to prevent complications like posterior synechiae and secondary glaucoma.

questions.text: A young patient presents to the ophthalmic outpatient department with gradual blurring of vision in the left eye. Slit-lamp examination reveals fine stellate keratic precipitates, aqueous flare, and a typical complicated posterior subcapsular cataract. No posterior synechiae were observed. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heterochromic Iridocyclitis of Fuch’s

 

Fuchs Heterochromic Iridocyclitis presents with a characteristic clinical picture that matches this case. The condition features fine stellate keratic precipitates distributed across the cornea and a low-grade anterior chamber inflammation with aqueous flare. A hallmark feature is the presence of posterior subcapsular cataract (PSC) as a complication. Most importantly, Fuchs specifically lacks posterior synechiae formation despite chronic inflammation, which is a distinguishing feature noted in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intermediate Uveitis (Pars Planitis): This condition primarily affects the ciliary body and vitreous rather than the anterior chamber. Its characteristic findings include "snowball" opacities in the vitreous and "snowbanking" at the ora serrata, not stellate keratic precipitates. Macular edema rather than PSC cataract would be the primary complication affecting vision.

 

Option B. Heerfordt's Disease: This is a specific manifestation of sarcoidosis presenting with uveitis, parotid gland enlargement, facial nerve palsy, and fever. Sarcoidosis typically causes granulomatous uveitis with "mutton fat" keratic precipitates rather than the stellate KPs described here, and posterior synechiae would typically form.

 

Option D. Subacute Iridocyclitis: This general term refers to an intermediate duration anterior uveitis. It would typically present with posterior synechiae formation, which is specifically absent in this case. Additionally, the characteristic stellate KPs described are specific to Fuchs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The combination of stellate keratic precipitates, aqueous flare, posterior subcapsular cataract, and specifically the absence of posterior synechiae despite chronic inflammation strongly points to Fuchs Heterochromic Iridocyclitis, which follows the FUCHS mnemonic: Floaters, Unilateral uveitis, Complicated cataract, Heterochromia, Stellate KPs with Synechiae absent.

questions.text: An infant presents with bilateral white pupillary reflex. On slit lamp examination, a zone of opacity is observed around the fetal nucleus with spoke-like radial opacities. The most likely diagnosis is? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lamellar cataract

 

The clinical presentation describes a classic lamellar (zonular) cataract, which is characterized by opacity occupying a discrete zone in the lens around the fetal nucleus. The pathognomonic feature is the presence of "riders" - small linear opacities like spokes of a wheel that extend toward the equator. This perfectly matches the description of "spoke-like radial opacities" in the case.

 

This is the most common type of congenital cataract presenting with visual impairment. It typically occurs in a zone of fetal nucleus surrounding the embryonic nucleus. The main mass of the lens internal and external to the zone of cataract is clear, with small linear opacities like spokes of a wheel (riders) seen towards the equator, exactly matching the described presentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cataracta Centralis Pulvurulenta: Incorrect. This is an embryonic nuclear cataract characterized by a small rounded opacity lying exactly in the center of the lens with a powdery appearance. It doesn't present with the discrete zone of opacity surrounding the fetal nucleus or the spoke-like radial opacities (riders) described in the case.

 

Option C. Coronary cataract: Incorrect. Coronary cataracts are characterized by club-shaped opacities with a regular radial distribution in the periphery of the lens encircling the central axis. They don't form a zone around the fetal nucleus as described in the case.

 

Option D. Posterior polar cataract: Incorrect. This involves a small circular circumscribed opacity at the posterior pole, not a zone around the fetal nucleus. The progressive form typically has an "onion whorl appearance," not the spoke-like radial opacities described.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Lamellar cataract is characterized by opacity in a discrete zone around the fetal nucleus with pathognomonic "riders" (spoke-like radial opacities extending toward the equator), making it the most common type of visually significant congenital cataract.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with deterioration of vision 3 weeks after cataract extraction and intraocular lens (IOL) implantation. Slit-lamp examination reveals honeycomb maculopathy, and fluorescein angiography shows ‘flower petal’ hyperfluorescence. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cystoid Macular Edema

 

This patient presents with classic features of Cystoid Macular Edema (CME), particularly the Irvine-Gass syndrome, which is CME occurring after cataract surgery. The key diagnostic elements are: 

 

  • Deterioration of vision after cataract surgery (a common timing for CME)
  • Honeycomb appearance of macula on slit-lamp examination
  • The pathognomonic "flower petal" pattern on fluorescein angiography, which represents leakage and accumulation of dye in the macular region.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age-Related Macular Degeneration (ARMD): This is incorrect as ARMD typically presents with drusen, pigmentary changes, or choroidal neovascularization. It does not show the classic "flower petal" pattern on fluorescein angiography and is not specifically related to recent cataract surgery.

 

Option B. Central Serous Retinopathy (CSR): This is incorrect as CSR typically affects younger patients, especially males with type A personality. On fluorescein angiography, CSR shows either "ink-blot" or "smoke-stack" patterns of hyperfluorescence, not the flower petal appearance.

 

Option C. Macular Dystrophy: This is incorrect as macular dystrophies are genetic disorders with gradual onset, not suddenly appearing after cataract surgery. They also don't typically present with the honeycomb appearance or flower petal pattern on fluorescein angiography.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cystoid Macular Edema is a common complication after cataract surgery (Irvine-Gass syndrome), characterized by honeycomb appearance on clinical examination and flower petal pattern on fluorescein angiography due to leakage from macular capillaries.

questions.text: The wavelength of the laser (in nanometers) used for shaping the cornea in refractive surgery is? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 193 nm

 

The excimer laser used for refractive surgery procedures like LASIK and PRK operates at a wavelength of 193 nanometers, which is in the ultraviolet (UV) range. This specific wavelength is produced by excited dimers (hence the name "excimer") of argon and fluoride gases. The 193 nm wavelength is precisely absorbed by corneal tissue, allowing for accurate photoablation of the corneal stroma without thermal damage to surrounding tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 451 nm: This is incorrect. 451 nm falls in the visible blue light spectrum and is not used for corneal refractive surgery. This wavelength would not provide the precise photoablative effect needed to reshape the cornea without thermal damage.

 

Option C. 532 nm: This is incorrect. The 532 nm wavelength is in the visible green light spectrum and is typically used in some ophthalmic laser procedures like selective laser trabeculoplasty (SLT) for glaucoma treatment, not for corneal refractive surgery.

 

Option D. 1064 nm: This is incorrect. The 1064 nm wavelength is in the near-infrared spectrum and is used in Nd: YAG lasers for posterior capsulotomy after cataract surgery or for peripheral iridotomy in angle-closure glaucoma. The femtosecond laser used to create corneal flaps in LASIK uses wavelengths around 1054 nm, but this is distinct from the excimer laser that actually reshapes the cornea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 193 nm ultraviolet excimer laser provides the precise ablation characteristics needed for corneal refractive procedures, allowing for accurate tissue removal without thermal damage to surrounding structures - a critical factor in achieving predictable visual outcomes in refractive surgery.

questions.text: Ring of Soemmering is seen in? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lens Capsule

 

Ring of Soemmering (Soemmering's ring) is a thick ring of after-cataract that forms between the two layers of the lens capsule. It develops following extracapsular cataract extraction when residual cortical lens material becomes trapped in the peripheral part of the capsular bag. This ring forms behind the iris, enclosed between the anterior and posterior lens capsule, and represents a type of secondary or after-cataract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wilson's disease: Wilson's disease (hepatolenticular degeneration) is associated with "sunflower cataract" characterized by yellowish-brown dots deposited in the anterior lens capsule in a stellate pattern, and Kayser-Fleischer ring in the cornea, not Soemmering's ring.

 

Option B. Retinitis pigmentosa: This is a degenerative retinal condition that may be associated with posterior subcapsular cataract as a complication, but has no relation to Soemmering's ring formation.

 

Option C. Siderosis bulbi: This condition results from intraocular iron foreign body and causes rusty-brown discoloration of ocular tissues. It has no specific association with Soemmering's ring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Soemmering's ring represents residual cortical lens material trapped in the peripheral part between the anterior and posterior lens capsule following extracapsular cataract extraction, forming a characteristic ring-like structure behind the iris.

questions.text: Which of the following is the layer between the choroid and the retina? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bruch's membrane

 

Bruch's membrane is the layer situated between the choroid and the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), which is the outermost layer of the retina. It serves as a basement membrane to which the RPE is firmly adherent. This anatomical relationship is fundamental to understanding many retinal pathologies such as age-related macular degeneration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Descemet's membrane: This is incorrect as Descemet's membrane is located in the cornea, specifically between the corneal stroma and the corneal endothelium, not in the retina.

 

Option C. Photoreceptors: This is incorrect as photoreceptors (rods and cones) form the second layer of the retina, not the interface between choroid and retina. They are located within the neurosensory retina above the RPE.

 

Option D. Ganglion cell layer: This is incorrect as the ganglion cell layer is the eighth layer of the retina, containing cell bodies of ganglion cells, and is located much more internally than the choroid-retina interface.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bruch's membrane serves as a critical boundary between the vascular choroid and the retinal pigment epithelium, playing an important role in nutrient exchange and waste removal for the outer retinal layers.

questions.text: Which of the following tonometry techniques utilizes the Imbert-Fick Law Principle? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Applanation Tonometry

 

Applanation tonometry is specifically based on the Imbert-Fick Law (P=F/A), where pressure equals force divided by area. This principle states that the pressure inside an ideal sphere equals the force necessary to flatten its surface divided by the area of flattening. In applanation tonometry, the instrument's footplate flattens the cornea, and the pressure required for this flattening directly correlates with intraocular pressure. Fluorescein dye is used during the procedure, viewed under cobalt blue light to identify when the mires juxtapose each other, indicating the measurement endpoint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Indentation Tonometry: This method, exemplified by the Schiotz tonometer, works on a different principle where a plunger indents the cornea. It depends on the relationship between the depth of corneal indentation and intraocular pressure, and is affected by scleral rigidity. It does not utilize the Imbert-Fick Law.

 

Option C. Dynamic Contour Tonometry: This is a more recent technique using a contoured tip that matches the shape of the cornea to minimize distortion. It uses a pressure sensor to directly measure intraocular pressure rather than applying the Imbert-Fick principle.

 

Option D. Rebound Tonometry: This technique involves propelling a small probe toward the cornea and analyzing its rebound characteristics. The deceleration of the probe upon corneal impact correlates with IOP. It works on principles of motion dynamics rather than the Imbert-Fick Law.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Imbert-Fick Law (P=F/A) is the fundamental principle behind applanation tonometry, where the force required to flatten a specific area of cornea directly correlates with intraocular pressure - making it the gold standard for IOP measurement.

questions.text: What is the name for the association of intraocular hemorrhage with subarachnoid hemorrhage? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Terson’s Syndrome

 

Terson syndrome refers to the combination of bilateral intraocular hemorrhages (including intraretinal, subhyaloid, and vitreous hemorrhage) associated with subarachnoid hemorrhage due to aneurysmal rupture. This condition represents a significant ophthalmological manifestation of intracranial bleeding events.

 

Other Options:

 

Options B. Duane's Syndrome: This is a congenital eye movement disorder characterized by limited abduction, adduction, or both, with narrowing of the palpebral fissure and retraction of the globe on adduction. It has no relation to hemorrhage.

 

Options C. Brown's Syndrome: This is a restriction of elevation of the eye in adduction due to a problem with the superior oblique tendon sheath complex. It is not related to hemorrhagic conditions.

 

Options D. Tolosa Hunt Syndrome: This is a painful ophthalmoplegia caused by nonspecific inflammation of the cavernous sinus or superior orbital fissure. It is not associated with intraocular or subarachnoid hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Terson syndrome represents a critical ocular manifestation of subarachnoid hemorrhage, specifically featuring intraocular hemorrhages in association with aneurysmal rupture, which serves as an important diagnostic sign of intracranial bleeding

questions.text: A regular contact lens user presents with complaints of severe pain, redness, photophobia, and blurring of vision for more than two weeks, not responding to standard treatment. On examination, a paracentral ring-shaped lesion with stromal infiltrates and overlying epithelial defects is observed in the affected eye. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acanthamoeba keratitis

 

  • This is a classic presentation of Acanthamoeba keratitis. 
  • The key diagnostic features include:
    • History of contact lens use (most common risk factor)
    • Severe pain that is disproportionate to clinical signs
    • Ring infiltrate in the cornea (pathognomonic sign)
    • Non-responsive to conventional antimicrobial therapy
    • Chronicity of symptoms (over two weeks)

 

Supporting Evidence:

 

Acanthamoeba keratitis presents with characteristic ring infiltrates, central or paracentral, with overlying epithelial defects. The most common predisposing factor is contact lens wear, particularly with improper lens hygiene or exposure to contaminated water.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial keratitis:

 

  • Typically responds to antibiotics within days
  • Pain is proportionate to clinical signs
  • Most common organism in contact lens users is Pseudomonas (causes hypopyon ulcer)
  • Does not characteristically form ring infiltrates
  • Usually has quicker onset and progression

 

Option C. Viral keratitis:

 

  • Characterized by dendritic or geographic patterns (herpes simplex)
  • Usually has reduced corneal sensations
  • Responds to antiviral therapy
  • Does not form ring-shaped infiltrates
  • Often has history of recurrence

 

Option D. Fungal keratitis:

 

  • Typically has history of vegetative matter injury
  • Shows feathery margins with satellite lesions
  • Cheesy necrotic appearance of ulcer base
  • May have Wessley immune ring but not typical ring infiltrates as seen in Acanthamoeba
  • Signs are usually more prominent than symptoms

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ring-shaped stromal infiltrates in a contact lens wearer with severe pain disproportionate to clinical signs and non-responsive to conventional antimicrobial therapy is pathognomonic for Acanthamoeba keratitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Vogt's triad in primary angle closure glaucoma? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Goniosynechiae

 

Vogt's triad is seen in both treated and non-treated cases after an attack of acute primary angle closure (PAC). It is specifically characterized by three distinct features: glaukomflecken (anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity), patches of iris atrophy, and a slightly dilated nonreacting pupil due to sphincter atrophy. Goniosynechiae (peripheral anterior synechiae) are not part of Vogt's triad, though they are common findings in angle closure glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iris atrophy: This is a component of Vogt's triad. Patches of iris atrophy occur due to ischemic damage during the acute attack and represent one of the three classic findings.

 

Option C. Non-reacting pupil: This is a component of Vogt's triad. The slightly dilated, non-reactive pupil results from sphincter atrophy caused by ischemia during the acute attack.

 

Option D. Glaukomflecken: These are correctly described as part of Vogt's triad. Glaukomflecken are anterior subcapsular lenticular opacities that develop following an acute attack of angle closure glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vogt's triad consists of glaukomflecken (anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity), patches of iris atrophy, and slightly dilated non reacting pupil due to sphincter atrophy—it is a classic finding following an attack of acute primary angle closure glaucoma, while goniosynechiae represent a different pathological finding in this condition.

questions.text: A neonate is brought to the OPD with complaints of redness and discharge from both the eyes, raising a suspicion of ophthalmia neonatorum. What is the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chlamydia

 

Explanation : 


Chlamydia is the most common bacterial cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries.


Ophthalmia neonatorum is a type of conjunctivitis seen in the neonatal period,  presenting  5-14 days after birth with red eyes and discharge. It commonly gets transmitted during vaginal delivery. Requires antibiotic treatment.

 


Other Options:

 

Option B. Gonorrhea: Severe, purulent conjunctivitis presenting 2-5 days after birth. It commonly gets transmitted during vaginal delivery, and it correlates with severe complications such as corneal ulceration and perforation, which can potentially result in permanent blindness. Requires Urgent antibiotic treatment.

 

Option C. Chemical conjunctivitis : occurs within 24 hrs , Caused by 1% AgNO3 Crede's method used to prevent ophthalmia neonatorum. Presents with mild inflammation, redness, and tearing, and usually resolves on its own.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus: Less common cause, presenting with mild to moderate redness and discharge. Treated with topical antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective: 
 

 

(REF: Matejcek A, Goldman RD. Treatment and prevention of ophthalmia neonatorum. Can Fam Physician. 2013 Nov;59(11):1187-90. PMID: 24235191; PMCID: PMC3828094.)

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient underwent uneventful phacoemulsification with IOL implantation. On the third postoperative day, he presented with pain, diminished vision, redness, watering, and a grayish-yellow pupillary reflex. Examination revealed circumcorneal congestion, aqueous cells 4+, hypopyon in the anterior chamber, posterior synechiae, and retrolental flare. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endophthalmitis

 

This case presents a classic picture of bacterial endophthalmitis following cataract surgery. The presentation on postoperative day three with severe pain, marked diminution of vision, circumcorneal congestion, hypopyon, and a grayish-yellow pupillary reflex are hallmark signs. Bacterial endophthalmitis typically presents between 48-72 hours after surgery with precisely these symptoms and signs.

 

This is an emergency complication of cataract surgery with an incidence of 0.1-0.5%. The symptoms and signs typically present between 48-72 hours after surgery and include ocular pain, diminished vision, lid edema, conjunctival chemosis, marked circumciliary congestion, corneal edema, exudates in pupillary area, hypopyon, and diminished or absent red pupillary glow. This exactly matches the patient's presentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratitis: Incorrect. While keratitis (corneal inflammation) can cause pain, redness and diminished vision, it would primarily present with corneal findings such as infiltrates, epithelial defects, or corneal edema. The presentation with hypopyon, aqueous cells, posterior synechiae, and grayish-yellow pupillary reflex points to a more extensive intraocular inflammation.

 

Option B. Glaucoma: Incorrect. Postoperative glaucoma may cause pain and diminished vision, but it wouldn't explain the marked inflammatory signs including hypopyon, posterior synechiae, and significant aqueous cells. The grayish-yellow pupillary reflex also wouldn't be a feature of glaucoma.

 

Option D. Iridocorneal Cyclitis: Incorrect. While this would cause inflammation of the iris and ciliary body with pain and anterior chamber reaction, it typically wouldn't present with the severity described, especially the grayish-yellow pupillary reflex which suggests vitreous involvement. Postoperative anterior uveitis is typically less severe than the presentation described.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bacterial endophthalmitis following cataract surgery is an emergency characterized by presenting 48-72 hours postoperatively with severe pain, marked visual loss, hypopyon, and exudates in the pupillary area requiring immediate intervention with intravitreal antibiotics.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Argyll Robertson Pupil is incorrect? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Consensual Light Reflex Normal

 

Argyll Robertson Pupil (ARP) is characterized by small, irregular pupils that accommodate but do not react to light - showing light-near dissociation. Both direct and consensual light reflexes are absent in ARP, while the near reflex remains intact. The consensual light reflex is absent, not normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Near Reflex Normal: The accommodation reflex is preserved in ARP. This is the key feature of light-near dissociation.

 

Option B. Direct Light Reflex Absent: This is a correct description of ARP, as the direct pupillary response to light is absent.

 

Option D. Visual Acuity Normal: Visual acuity is not affected by the pupillary abnormality in ARP.

 

Additional features of Argyll Robertson Pupil:

 

  • Bilateral involvement with small, irregular pupils
  • Pupils dilate poorly with mydriatics
  • Most commonly seen in tertiary neurosyphilis
  • Can also occur in diabetes, Wernicke's encephalopathy, and midbrain tumors
  • Caused by a lesion in the pretectal area of the midbrain

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Argyll Robertson Pupil shows complete light-near dissociation with absence of both direct and consensual light reflexes, while accommodation (near) reflex is preserved.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causing acute bacterial conjunctivitis is NOT associated with a Polymorphonuclear response? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Moraxella lacunata

 

Moraxella lacunata causes angular bacterial conjunctivitis, which is a distinct clinical entity with different characteristics from typical acute bacterial conjunctivitis. This organism produces a proteolytic enzyme that macerates epithelium at the angles of the eye rather than triggering the classic polymorphonuclear inflammatory response seen with other bacterial pathogens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Staphylococcus aureus:As the most common cause of bacterial conjunctivitis, Staphylococcus aureus infection typically presents with a marked polymorphonuclear inflammatory response, characterized by neutrophil infiltration in cytological specimens.

 

Option C. Haemophilus influenzae: This organism (especially H. aegyptius/Koch-Weeks bacillus) causes epidemic mucopurulent conjunctivitis with significant polymorphonuclear response, contributing to the characteristic purulent discharge.

 

Option D. Streptococcus pneumoniae: Pneumococcal conjunctivitis is associated with not only a polymorphonuclear response but also typically presents with petechial subconjunctival hemorrhages, distinguishing it clinically while still maintaining the neutrophilic infiltration pattern.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Angular conjunctivitis caused by Moraxella lacunata has distinct pathophysiology involving epithelial maceration rather than the typical polymorphonuclear infiltration seen with other bacterial conjunctival infections, making it uniquely different in its inflammatory response pattern.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with uniocular diplopia. Examination with oblique illumination shows a golden crescent, while examination with co-axial illumination shows a dark crescent line. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ectopia lentis

 

This patient presents with classic signs of subluxation of the lens (ectopia lentis), which is a partial displacement where the lens is moved sideways but remains behind the pupil. The key diagnostic findings include uniocular diplopia and the characteristic appearance of the lens edge visible as a dark crescent on distant direct (co-axial) illumination and as a shining golden crescent on oblique illumination examination.

 

Subluxation of the lens (a form of ectopia lentis) presents with uniocular diplopia due to partial aphakia. The edge of the subluxated lens is seen as a dark crescent on distant direct (co-axial) ophthalmoscopy and as a shining golden crescent on oblique illumination, exactly matching the clinical findings described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lenticonus: Incorrect. Lenticonus refers to a cone-shaped elevation of either the anterior or posterior pole of the lens. It presents as an "oil globule" appearance in the center of the red reflex on distant direct ophthalmoscopy, not as a crescent. It doesn't typically cause uniocular diplopia.

 

Option B. Coloboma: Incorrect. Coloboma of the lens appears as a notch in the lower quadrant of the equator of the lens. While it is a structural abnormality, it doesn't cause the characteristic golden/dark crescent sign described, nor is it typically associated with uniocular diplopia.

 

Option C. Microspherophakia: Incorrect. In microspherophakia, the lens is spherical in shape and small in size. While microspherophakia can be associated with lens displacement, the primary finding would be the small, spherical lens rather than just the crescentic signs described.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Subluxated lens (ectopia lentis) has pathognomonic findings of uniocular diplopia and visualization of the lens edge as a dark crescent on co-axial illumination and a golden crescent on oblique illumination.
